reviews.text:
An alright station, there is a manned ticket office, a toilet and a coffee stand which are open until 10:30 am, the staff in the ticket office are knowledge and helpful and the man that runs the coffee stand is great.
However other than that there is nothing around, not even a toilet (as the toilet is locked after 10:30) so it's not a good station to be stranded at for long, especially as many of the trains in to Wales pass through and many people change trains here.

A very quiet station, situated on the entrance to the Welsh portal of the Severn tunnel.  There are 4 platforms. 2 share the line to London and Bristol, while the other 2 ascend towards Gloucester, Cheltenham and the North. Both routes will take commuters to Cardiff for onward travel.
The station itself has a rather uneven surface in places. The shelters are spacious but do tend to let the cold wind in and act as a green house during the summer...
Services are a little on thin side, but certainly isn't the worst of the UK network.
The car park is reasonably sized but not fantastic. A local bus service dies also pick up from there.
Overall, its alright, but not overly amazing
All weather cover. Wheelchair accessible.  Car park. Departure boards.

Got stranded here, absolutely nothing to pass the time in the surrounded area, one of the most desolate stations I've been to. :(

Edit: I was told after I got home that the train companies are meant to find alternative transport such as a taxi if you miss a second train (the last one) because the first had arrived late. I was not notified this by the number that I had phoned on the digital station display. No love for Arriva Trains Wales, I'm afraid.
